Package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab

Class ColorfulBatch

java.lang.Object
com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab.ColorfulBatch
All Implemented Interfaces:
com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch, com.badlogic.gdx.utils.Disposable
public class ColorfulBatch
extends java.lang.Object
implements com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch
A substitute for SpriteBatch that adds an additional attribute to store an extra color's worth of channels, used to modify the L, A, and B channels of a color by multiplication (called the "tweak") while the primary color affects the color additively (just called the color, often drawn from Palette or generated with ColorTools). This ColorfulBatch uses the Oklab color space where SpriteBatch normally uses RGBA, which means that in the batch color, red maps to additive L (lightness), green maps to additive A (green-to-red), blue maps to additive B (violet-to-yellow), and alpha continues to be multiplicative alpha. Additive values cause no change when they are 0.5, but cause a sharp increase at 1.0 and a sharp decrease at 0.0. In the tweak, red maps to multiplicative L, green maps to multiplicative A, blue maps to multiplicative B, and alpha maps to "exponential-like" contrast. Like with the additive values, 0.5 causes no change for multiplicative values, but you can think of the existing color as being temporarily shifted down by 0.5 for each of the LAB channels, so each LAB channel's range is -0.5 to 0.5 before being multiplied by the corresponding tweak value (times 2.0, which means multiplicative tweak values for A and B that are less than 0.5 make colors closer to grayscale and values greater than 0.5 make colors more vibrant) and then shifted back to its prior range. Contrast is a special value; 0.5 still means "no change," but lower values will make L changes less distinct between similar colors, while higher values will "sharpen" the changes in L.
Created by Tommy Ettinger on 1/21/2021.

    • color

      protected float color

    • TWEAK_RESET

      public static final float TWEAK_RESET
      A constant packed float that can be assigned to this ColorfulBatch's tweak with setTweak(float) to make all of the tweak adjustments virtually imperceptible. When this is set as the tweak, it won't change the L multiplier or contrast, and it won't change the A multiplier or the B multiplier.

      See Also:
      ColorfulBatch(int, ShaderProgram)

    • ColorfulBatch

      public ColorfulBatch​(int size, com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.glutils.ShaderProgram defaultShader)
      Constructs a new ColorfulBatch. Sets the projection matrix to an orthographic projection with y-axis point upwards, x-axis point to the right and the origin being in the bottom left corner of the screen. The projection will be pixel perfect with respect to the current screen resolution.

      The defaultShader specifies the shader to use. Note that the names for uniforms for this default shader are different than the ones expect for shaders set with setShader(ShaderProgram). See createDefaultShader().

      Parameters:
      size - The max number of sprites in a single batch. Max of 10922.
      defaultShader - The default shader to use. This is not owned by the ColorfulBatch and must be disposed separately.

      public void setColor​(com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Color tint)
      Specified by:
      setColor in interface com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch

    • setColor

      public void setColor​(float L, float A, float B, float alpha)
      Sets the color to the result of ColorTools.oklab(float, float, float, float) on the same arguments. For the L/A/B parameters, 0.5f is a neutral value (causing no change), while for alpha, 1.0f is a neutral value. For L/A/B, higher values will add to the corresponding channel, while lower values will subtract from it.
      Specified by:
      setColor in interface com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch
      Parameters:
      L - like lightness; additive; ranges from 0 (black) to 1 (white)
      A - cool-to-warm, roughly; additive; ranges from 0 (green/cyan/blue) to 1 (orange/red/purple)
      B - artificial-to-natural, very roughly; additive; ranges from 0 (blue/purple) to 1 (green/yellow/orange)
      alpha - opacity, from 0 to 1; multiplicative
      See Also:
      ColorTools.oklab(float, float, float, float)

    • setColor

      public void setColor​(float color)

    • setIntColor

      public void setIntColor​(int color)

    • setIntColor

      public void setIntColor​(int L, int A, int B, int alpha)
      Sets the color with the given L/A/B and A parameters from 0 to 255. For the L/A/B parameters, 127 or 128 is a neutral value (causing no change), while for alpha, 255 is a neutral value. For L/A/B, higher values will add to the corresponding channel, while lower values will subtract from it.
      Parameters:
      L - like lightness; additive; ranges from 0 (black) to 255 (white)
      A - cool-to-warm, roughly; additive; ranges from 0 (green/cyan/blue) to 255 (orange/red/purple)
      B - artificial-to-natural, very roughly; additive; ranges from 0 (blue/purple) to 255 (green/yellow/orange)
      alpha - opacity, from 0 to 255 (254 is equivalent, since the lowest bit is discarded); multiplicative
      See Also:
      ColorTools.oklab(float, float, float, float)

      getPackedColor in interface com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch

    • setTweak

      public void setTweak​(float L, float A, float B, float contrast)
      Sets the multiplicative and contrast parts of the shader's color changes. 0.5 is a neutral value that should have minimal effect on the image; using (0.5f, 0.5f, 0.5f, 0.5f) will effectively remove the tweak.
      Parameters:
      L - like lightness; multiplicative; ranges from 0 (sets lightness to 0) to 1 (doubles lightness)
      A - cool-to-warm, roughly; multiplicative; ranges from 0 (green and red are removed) to 1 (green-ness or red-ness is emphasized)
      B - artificial-to-natural, very roughly; multiplicative; ranges from 0 (blue and yellow are removed) to 1 (blue-ness or yellow-ness is emphasized)
      contrast - affects how lightness changes; ranges from 0 (low contrast, cloudy look) to 1 (high contrast, sharpened look)

    • setTweak

      public void setTweak​(float tweak)
      Sets the tweak using a single packed Oklab float.
      Parameters:
      tweak - a packed Oklab float, with contrast instead of alpha
      See Also:
      setTweak(float, float, float, float)

    • getTweak

      public float getTweak()

    • setIntTweak

      public void setIntTweak​(int tweak)
      Takes the tweak as an int in the format: L (8 bits), A (8 bits), B (8 bits), contrast (7 bits), (1 ignored bit at the end). An example would be 0x7820206E, which slightly darkens (with L 0x78, slightly below the halfway point of 0x80), significantly reduces colorfulness with A and B multipliers of 0x20 (closer to 0, so most colors will be almost grayscale), and slightly reduces contrast (with contrast and the ignored bit as 0x6E, which is less than the halfway point).
      Parameters:
      tweak - the tweak to use as an integer, with L in the most significant bits and contrast in least

    • setIntTweak

      public void setIntTweak​(int L, int A, int B, int contrast)
      Sets the multiplicative and contrast parts of the shader's color changes. 127 is a neutral value that should have minimal effect on the image; using (127, 127, 127, 127) will effectively remove the tweak.
      Parameters:
      L - like lightness; multiplicative; ranges from 0 (black) to 255 (white)
      A - cool-to-warm, roughly; multiplicative; ranges from 0 (green and red are removed) to 255 (green-ness or red-ness is emphasized)
      B - artificial-to-natural, very roughly; multiplicative; ranges from 0 (blue and yellow are removed) to 255 (blue-ness or yellow-ness is emphasized)
      contrast - affects how lightness changes; ranges from 0 (low contrast, cloudy look) to 255 (high contrast, sharpened look)

    • setTweakedColor

      public void setTweakedColor​(float color, float tweak)
      A convenience method that sets both the color (with setColor(float)) and the tweak (with setTweak(float)) at the same time, using two packed floats.
      Parameters:
      color - the additive components and alpha, as a packed float
      tweak - the multiplicative components and contrast, as a packed float

    • setTweakedColor

      public void setTweakedColor​(float addL, float addA, float addB, float mulAlpha, float mulL, float mulA, float mulB, float contrast)
      A convenience method that sets both the color (with setColor(float, float, float, float)) and the tweak (with setTweak(float, float, float, float)) at the same time.
      Parameters:
      addL - like lightness; additive; ranges from 0 (black) to 1 (white)
      addA - cool-to-warm, roughly; additive; ranges from 0 (green/cyan/blue) to 1 (orange/red/purple)
      addB - artificial-to-natural, very roughly; additive; ranges from 0 (blue/purple) to 1 (green/yellow/orange)
      mulAlpha - opacity, from 0 to 1; multiplicative
      mulL - like lightness; multiplicative; ranges from 0 (sets all L to 0) to 1 (doubles the image's L)
      mulA - cool-to-warm, roughly; multiplicative; ranges from 0 (green/cyan/blue) to 1 (orange/red/purple)
      mulB - artificial-to-natural, very roughly; multiplicative; ranges from 0 (blue/purple) to 1 (green/yellow/orange)
      contrast - foggy-to-sharp lightness contrast; affects most other components; ranges from 0 (flat, foggy lightness) to 1 (sharp, crisp lightness)

    • draw

      public void draw​(com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Texture texture, float[] spriteVertices, int offset, int count)
      This is very different from the other overloads in this class; it assumes the float array it is given is in the format libGDX uses to give to SpriteBatch, that is, in groups of 20 floats per sprite. ColorfulBatch uses 24 floats per sprite, to add tweak per color, so this does some conversion.
      Specified by:
      draw in interface com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch
      Parameters:
      texture - the Texture being drawn from; usually an atlas or some parent Texture with lots of TextureRegions
      spriteVertices - not the same format as vertices in this class; should have a length that's a multiple of 20
      offset - where to start drawing vertices from spriteVertices
      count - how many vertices to draw from spriteVertices (20 vertices is one sprite)

    • drawExactly

      public void drawExactly​(com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Texture texture, float[] spriteVertices, int offset, int count)
      Meant for code that uses ColorfulBatch specifically and can set an extra float (for the color tweak) per vertex, this is just like draw(Texture, float[], int, int) when used in other Batch implementations, but expects spriteVertices to have a length that is a multiple of 24 instead of 20.
      Parameters:
      texture - the Texture being drawn from; usually an atlas or some parent Texture with lots of TextureRegions
      spriteVertices - vertices formatted as this class uses them; length should be a multiple of 24
      offset - where to start drawing vertices from spriteVertices
      count - how many vertices to draw from spriteVertices (24 vertices is one sprite)
